Ans: R-squared and Adjusted R-squared are both measures used in regression analysis to assess the goodness-of-fit of a model, but they differ in how they account for the number of independent variables. ð‘…2 represents the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that can be explained by the independent variables in the model where Adjusted R-squared is a modified version of ð‘…2 that adjusts for the number of independent variables in the model and the sample size. It penalizes the inclusion of unnecessary predictors.Adjusted R-squared is more suitable for comparing models with different numbers of predictors, as it accounts for model complexity. ð‘…2 can be misleading in such comparisons.

We donâ€™t reject null hyphothesis for enginesize because its p-value is 0.187, which is bigger than 0.05.That means, after we already account for Horsepower and CurbWeight, Engine Size doesnâ€™t add clear, extra predictive power for MPG.Also, Engine Size and Horsepower are highly correlated (\~0.92), so they carry overlapping information; this multicollinearity makes Engine Sizeâ€™s estimate noisy (large SE) and therefore not statistically significant.
